<ref>{{cite web |title=How Apple Can Trademark 'App Store'|url=http://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2382968,00.asp|publisher=[[PC Magazine]] |date=1 Apr 2011 |accessdate=18 Apr 2011}}</ref>.U.S. District Judge Phyllis Hamilton, who is presiding over Apple's case against Amazon, said she'll "probably" deny Apple's motion that seeks to bar the Web retailer from using the "App Store" name.<ref>http://news.cnet.com/8301-27076_3-20073524-248/judge-likely-to-deny-apples-appstore-complaint/</ref><ref>http://www.businessweek.com/news/2011-06-22/apple-bid-to-bar-amazon-appstore-will-likely-be-denied.html</ref><ref>http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/06/22/us-apple-amazon-idUSTRE75L79Y20110622</ref>
+
<ref>{{cite web |title=How Apple Can Trademark 'App Store'|url=http://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2382968,00.asp|publisher=[[PC Magazine]] |date=1 Apr 2011 |accessdate=18 Apr 2011}}</ref>. Later, in June 2001, U.S. District Judge Phyllis Hamilton, who is presiding over Apple's case against Amazon, said she'll "probably" deny Apple's motion that seeks to bar the Web retailer from using the "App Store" name.<ref>http://news.cnet.com/8301-27076_3-20073524-248/judge-likely-to-deny-apples-appstore-complaint/</ref><ref>http://www.businessweek.com/news/2011-06-22/apple-bid-to-bar-amazon-appstore-will-likely-be-denied.html</ref><ref>http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/06/22/us-apple-amazon-idUSTRE75L79Y20110622</ref>
The term ''app'' has become a popular [[buzzword]]; in January 2011, ''app'' was awarded the honor of being 2010's "Word of the Year" by the [[American Dialect Society]].<ref>"[http://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5gO_3DHeXRb-b1CJCbGjRCUK1vVgQ?docId=1635c27d508b451396e873660a279cd6. Linguists vote 'app' Word of the Year"]. The Associated Press. 2011-01-07. Retrieved 2011-01-27.</ref> Apple does not hold a trademark on, or claim exclusive rights to the term ''app,'' which has been used as shorthand for "application" since at least 2002, for example [[Google Apps]] (first introduced in 2006).<ref>http://www.google.co.uk/#q=app+-application&hl=en&lr=&sa=X&rls=com.microsoft:en-us&tbs=cdr:1,cd_min:1/1/1998,cd_max:31/12/2007&fp=1&cad=b</ref>
The term ''app'' has become a popular [[buzzword]]; in January 2011, ''app'' was awarded the honor of being 2010's "Word of the Year" by the [[American Dialect Society]].<ref>"[http://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5gO_3DHeXRb-b1CJCbGjRCUK1vVgQ?docId=1635c27d508b451396e873660a279cd6. Linguists vote 'app' Word of the Year"]. The Associated Press. 2011-01-07. Retrieved 2011-01-27.</ref> Apple does not hold a trademark on, or claim exclusive rights to the term ''app,'' which has been used as shorthand for "application" since at least 2002, for example [[Google Apps]] (first introduced in 2006).<ref>http://www.google.co.uk/#q=app+-application&hl=en&lr=&sa=X&rls=com.microsoft:en-us&tbs=cdr:1,cd_min:1/1/1998,cd_max:31/12/2007&fp=1&cad=b</ref>
